title: Champion Bloodline Calf Develops Minor Defect
vignette: A rancher designated his best bull-calf for a prestigious national breeding program. Before transport, a veterinarian spots a small, disqualifying corneal scar.

options.text: Release the animal from the program by paying a set fee, the funds of which support the program.
Ignore the minor defect and send it to the program anyway.

title: Selling a Competition Animal Before Official Inspection
vignette: A farmer wants to sell a prize-winning lamb before the official program veterinarian has cleared it for competition. May he complete the sale first?

options.text: Prohibited until the program official examines it.
He may sell it with the stipulation that the buyer pays the program release fee if it's disqualified.

title: Program Official Waives Claim on Designated Animal
vignette: The program official declines to accept the designated calf, letting the owner keep it without paying the release fee.

options.text: Allowed; the official can use their discretion to waive the fee.
Not permitted; the designated animal belongs to the program until the fee is paid.

title: Private Use of a Specially Designated Animal After Disqualification
vignette: After a minor disqualifying defect is certified, a hobbyist asks to butcher the calf at home for family meat. Is that allowed once the disqualification paperwork is filed?

options.text: It must still be formally released from the program via the standard fee, out of an abundance of caution.
It can be treated as a regular animal since its defect was confirmed.

title: Commercial Resale of Meat from a Prize-Winning Animal
vignette: A chef buys a prize-winning steer that has been properly released from its program. He then plans to slice and sell "Champion Line" steaks at a premium. Is this resale appropriate?

options.text: Permitted once inspected and formally released from the program.
Forbidden; the special status of the animal means its meat should not be commercially exploited.

title: Using a Designated Animal for Labor Before Its Official Release
vignette: The owner uses his designated donkey for work before formally releasing it from the program by exchanging it for another animal.

options.text: He may work it temporarily.
He must release it from the program before any use.

title: Official Profiting From a Designated Animal
vignette: After processing, a program official wants to sell portions of a designated animal's meat for personal profit.

options.text: Allowed; it is part of their compensation.
Improper; the meat should be used for program purposes or shared without sale.

title: Lost Records for Specially Designated Animals
vignette: Breeding logs were lost; a farmer can't prove which of his animals were designated for the special program. How should he treat the doubtful animals?

options.text: Any animal whose status is in doubt is exempt from program rules.
All potentially designated animals must be treated as if they are in the program.

title: Status of Animal Designated Before Owner Joined Program
vignette: A farmer joins a prestigious breeding program after one of his cows gives birth. Does the calf have designated status?

options.text: Yes; the quality of the animal is what matters.
No; it was born before he was a member of the program.

title: Using a Designated Competition Animal for Labor
vignette: A heavyweight bull is idle in its pen. The owner wants to hitch it briefly to a plow while waiting for its official entry into a competition. Permitted?

options.text: Forbidden until it is either disqualified or released from the program.
Allowed if the work is brief and does not risk injury.

title: Delaying a Required Animal Exchange Due to Market Prices
vignette: Regulations require that a designated work-donkey must be exchanged for a healthy lamb by the end of the month. Lamb prices are unusually high, so the owner stalls. Is the delay acceptable?

options.text: Must exchange it promptly despite the cost.
A delay is acceptable until he can afford it.

title: Profiting From Byproducts of a Designated Animal
vignette: After processing a designated animal, the owner sells the hide.

options.text: Permissible; only the animal itself had special status.
He should not profit from any part of the designated animal.

title: Using Funds From Designated Animal Auctions for Public Works
vignette: Cash raised from auctioning designated animals now sits in a special account for the breeding program. The local town asks to use the funds to pave roads. Is that an acceptable use?

options.text: Yes; spending on community benefits is a proper use of the funds.
The funds should only be used to support the breeding program.

title: Designated Status for Animal Born via C-Section
vignette: A calf delivered surgically is the mother's first. Does it qualify for the prestigious 'firstborn' designation in the breeding program?

options.text: Yes; the birth method doesn't matter.
No; only animals born naturally qualify.

title: Confusing Two Different Regulatory Animal Programs
vignette: A rancher confuses the 'Designated Animal' registry with the 'Annual Herd Tax' levy and tries to process them together. Can one inspection cover both requirements?

options.text: Keep them distinct; each program has separate rules and requirements.
One process suffices for both for the sake of efficiency.
